title: This dad is running Boston to give back to Boston Children’s Hospital
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Nick Gallagher, 38, from Plymouth, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to support Boston Children's Hospital.
Gallagher's four-year-old son, a patient at Boston Children's Hospital, inspires his participation in the marathon.
He runs as part of the Miles for Miracles team, honoring the hospital's neurology care received by his family.

title: Her great-grandfather ran the Boston Marathon in 1920. Now she’s doing the same.
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Juliette Barney, 23, from Braintree, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the Youth Advocacy Foundation.
Her great-grandfather ran the Boston Marathon in 1920, inspiring her participation in the race.
Barney aims to raise awareness and funds for the Youth Advocacy Foundation, supporting youth facing systemic barriers.

title: Should Boston rebuild Madison Park at Roxbury’s P-3 site?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Boston's P-3 site in Roxbury may host a new Madison Park Technical Vocational High School amid changing development plans.
The Boston Planning & Development Agency's expired deal with developers was affected by declining demand for lab spaces.
Community and development opinions are divided on whether to proceed with housing or rebuild the vocational high school.

title: Tom Brady roasts Logan Paul, calls wrestler’s athletic abilities ‘cute’
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Tom Brady engaged in playful banter with Logan Paul on the 'IMPAULSIVE' podcast ahead of their upcoming flag football game.
Brady challenged Paul's athletic skill, contrasting it with NFL greats like Saquon Barkley and Odell Beckham Jr.
The Fanatics Flag Football Classic will occur on March 21 at Kingdom Arena in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, airing on Fox Sports.

title: Massachusetts emergency room wait times rank among the longest in the U.S.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts emergency room patients wait an average of 189 minutes, ranking the state third longest in the U.S.
ER wait times are driven by capacity issues and workforce shortages, according to the Massachusetts Health and Hospital Association.
Massachusetts has seen an increase in ER visits lasting 12+ hours, from 6.6% in 2020 to 9.9% in 2024.

title: Report: Retired 5x Pro Bowl left-tackle offers to help train Will Campbell
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Retired Pro Bowl tackle Terron Armstead offers to help Patriots' Will Campbell improve his technique during the offseason.
Campbell struggled in the Super Bowl, allowing pressures and contributing to ineffective line performance in protecting quarterback Drake Maye.
Armstead suggests Campbell’s issues are fixable and plans to work with him in Dallas, focusing on power and timing.

title: More than 400 readers voted: $240K in-office Boston job or $120K remote?
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: 56% of over 400 readers prefer a $240K in-person Boston job, while 40% favor a $120K remote role.
Supporters of the $120K remote job cite time and flexibility, with parents and commuters emphasizing work-life benefits.
Advocates for the $240K in-office position highlight salary benefits and a desire for in-person work environment.

title: City councilor calls for restrictions on e-bikes and mopeds, including ban for food delivery drivers
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Councilor Ed Flynn proposes banning e-bikes and mopeds for third-party delivery drivers to address public safety concerns.
New measures would require e-bike riders exceeding 30 mph to have a valid driver's license and register with the state.
DoorDash opposes the ban, citing potential economic impacts and increased car congestion in Boston's delivery sector.

title: Video shows corrections officers brawling in elevator at Boston jail
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: A brawl occurred among three female correctional officers at Suffolk County House of Correction on Saturday morning.
The fight in the elevator, partially triggered by a spilled coffee, was captured on video and showed officers struggling on the ground.
The Suffolk County Sheriff’s Department is investigating the incident and will decide on disciplinary actions based on their findings.

title: Asparagus could soon become Massachusetts’ official state vegetable
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Bill filed by Rep. Homar Gomez and Sen. Jo Comerford proposes asparagus as Massachusetts' official state vegetable.
Hadley, known as the 'asparagus capital of the world,' historically produced 80% of the nation's asparagus.
A statehouse committee is reviewing the bill, with potential for a public hearing involving local students.
